content.title: Solow Growth Model
content.definition: The Solow-Swan growth model (Solow 1956, Swan 1956) is the foundational neoclassical model of long-run economic growth. It explains how capital accumulation, labor force growth, and technological progress determine an economy's output and growth rate over time. The model's key insight is that capital accumulation alone cannot sustain growth indefinitely due to diminishing returns - economies converge to a 'steady state' where capital per worker and output per worker are constant. Only technological progress (exogenous in basic model) can sustain long-run growth in living standards. The model predicts convergence: poorer countries should grow faster than rich ones, catching up over time.

definitions_glossary.solow_model: Neoclassical growth model explaining long-run output as function of capital, labor, and technology: Y = F(K, AL)
definitions_glossary.production_function: Y = F(K, L) or Y = Kᵅ(AL)¹⁻ᵅ - relates inputs (capital, labor, technology) to output
definitions_glossary.capital_accumulation: K̇ = sY - δK - net investment equals savings minus depreciation of existing capital
definitions_glossary.steady_state: Long-run equilibrium where capital per effective worker k* is constant - economy grows at rate n + g
definitions_glossary.capital_per_worker: k = K/L - ratio of capital stock to labor force, key variable in per-worker analysis
definitions_glossary.output_per_worker: y = Y/L = f(k) - productivity, determined by capital per worker in intensive form
definitions_glossary.savings_rate: s = fraction of output saved and invested (exogenous in basic model, 0 < s < 1)
definitions_glossary.depreciation_rate: δ = fraction of capital stock that wears out each period (typically 3-5% annually)
definitions_glossary.labor_force_growth: n = growth rate of labor force L̇/L (exogenous, equals population growth if participation constant)
definitions_glossary.technological_progress: g = growth rate of labor-augmenting technology A - the ultimate source of sustained growth
definitions_glossary.effective_labor: AL = technology-adjusted labor input - grows at rate n + g in steady state
definitions_glossary.convergence: Prediction that poor countries grow faster than rich, catching up to steady state
definitions_glossary.golden_rule: Savings rate s* that maximizes steady-state consumption - where f'(k*) = δ + n + g

key_points: Production function: Y = Kᵅ(AL)¹⁻ᵅ (Cobb-Douglas) with constant returns to scale, diminishing returns to capital
Capital accumulation: K̇ = sY - δK. Net investment equals savings minus depreciation.
Steady state: Where sf(k) = (δ + n + g)k. Capital per effective worker constant, output grows at n + g
Diminishing returns: Adding more capital increases output at decreasing rate - can't grow forever by saving more
Transition dynamics: Below steady state k*, economy grows faster. Above k*, economy grows slower. Converges to k*
Convergence hypothesis: Poor countries (low k) should grow faster than rich countries (high k)
Conditional convergence: Countries converge to OWN steady state - depends on s, n, δ, g which vary by country
Technological progress (g) is the only source of sustained per capita growth in long run
Golden Rule: s* = α (capital share) maximizes steady-state consumption - not necessarily welfare-maximizing dynamically
Solow residual: TFP growth = Output growth - weighted input growth. Captures technology in data.

examples.title: Post-WWII Japan and Germany - Transition Growth
examples.description: Japan and Germany were devastated in 1945, with capital stocks destroyed. Solow model predicts: starting below steady state → rapid growth as capital accumulates. Japan grew 9%+ annually (1950s-60s), Germany 8%. As they approached steady state (caught up to US), growth slowed to 2-4%. Classic transition dynamics: rapid growth when k < k*, slowing as economy approaches steady state.
examples.context: Post-war reconstruction as transition to steady state
examples.data: Japan GDP growth: 9.3%/year (1950-73) → 3.8%/year (1974-90). Germany: 8% (1950s) → 3% (1970s). Per BEA, OECD data

examples.title: China's Rapid Growth (1980-2020)
examples.description: China started economic reforms in 1978 with very low capital per worker. Massive saving/investment (40%+ of GDP) drove rapid capital accumulation. Growth of 10%/year for three decades. Solow prediction: this is transition dynamics, not sustainable forever. As China approaches steady state, growth is slowing (6% by 2019, lower post-COVID). Debate: How much was capital accumulation vs TFP growth?
examples.data: China savings rate: 40%+ GDP. Growth: 10%/year (1980-2010) → 6%/year (2015+). Capital deepening + TFP both contributed

examples.title: Cross-Country Convergence - OECD vs Conditional
examples.description: Strong convergence among OECD countries 1950-2000: poorer European countries, Japan grew faster than rich US/UK. But globally: Africa, much of Latin America didn't converge to rich country levels. Resolution: CONDITIONAL convergence. Countries converge to own steady states. Low savings, high population growth, weak institutions → low steady state. Absolute convergence requires similar fundamentals.
examples.context: Evidence for conditional but not absolute convergence
examples.data: OECD convergence: correlation -0.9 between initial GDP and growth (1960-2000). Global: correlation weak

examples.title: Steady-State Calculation Example
examples.description: Economy with Y = K^0.3 L^0.7, s = 0.20, δ = 0.05, n = 0.02. In per-worker terms: y = k^0.3. Steady state: sk^0.3 = (δ+n)k = 0.07k. Solving: 0.20k^0.3 = 0.07k → k^(-0.7) = 0.35 → k* = 0.35^(-1/0.7) = 4.17. Output per worker: y* = 4.17^0.3 = 1.52. This is long-run equilibrium.
examples.data: Parameters: α=0.3, s=0.20, δ=0.05, n=0.02. Steady state: k*=4.17, y*=1.52

examples.title: Golden Rule - Optimal Savings
examples.description: What savings rate maximizes steady-state consumption? c* = f(k*) - (δ+n)k*. Maximize: f'(k*) = δ + n. With Cobb-Douglas: αk*^(α-1) = δ + n. Golden rule k* = (α/(δ+n))^(1/(1-α)). If actual s > s_gold: 'dynamically inefficient' - can consume more today AND in future by saving less. If s < s_gold: saving more increases long-run but not short-run consumption - tradeoff exists.
examples.context: Optimal savings rate for maximum consumption
examples.data: Golden rule condition: f'(k*) = δ + n + g. With Cobb-Douglas: s_gold = α (capital share ≈ 1/3)

content.statement: The Solow growth model is the foundational framework for understanding long-run economic growth, explaining how capital accumulation, labor force growth, and technological progress determine an economy's productive capacity. Its key insight - that sustained growth requires technological progress due to diminishing returns to capital - remains central to growth economics and development policy.

explanation.intuition: Imagine building a farm. Initially, adding more tractors (capital) dramatically increases output. But eventually, you have so many tractors that adding another barely helps - diminishing returns. If you keep buying tractors, the new ones just replace those breaking down (depreciation), not adding to your fleet. You reach a steady state where tractor-buying matches tractor-breaking. The only way to keep growing is better technology - more productive tractors or better farming techniques. The Solow model applies this logic to economies: save and invest all you want, but diminishing returns mean you'll converge to a steady state. Only innovation (g) keeps living standards rising forever.
explanation.key_insight: The profound insight is the distinction between LEVEL and GROWTH effects. Saving more (higher s) raises your steady-state level of output per worker but doesn't affect long-run growth rate. Only technology (g) determines long-run per capita growth. This has major policy implications: (1) Encouraging saving raises living standards but has diminishing returns and converges to new steady state. (2) Sustainable growth requires innovation policy, not just investment. (3) Convergence: poor countries should grow faster than rich ones as they're further from steady state - hopeful for development. But convergence is CONDITIONAL on having similar technology access and institutions.
explanation.technical_details: Production function: Y = Kᵅ(AL)¹⁻ᵅ where A is labor-augmenting technology. Define k̃ = K/AL (capital per effective worker), ỹ = Y/AL (output per effective worker). In effective units: ỹ = k̃ᵅ. Capital accumulation: K̇ = sY - δK. Dividing by AL and taking growth rates: dk̃/dt = sỹ - (δ + n + g)k̃ = sk̃ᵅ - (δ + n + g)k̃. Steady state: sk̃*ᵅ = (δ + n + g)k̃*, so k̃* = [s/(δ + n + g)]^(1/(1-α)). Output per effective worker: ỹ* = k̃*ᵅ = [s/(δ + n + g)]^(α/(1-α)). In steady state: Y/L grows at rate g (technology), Y grows at n + g. Growth accounting: ΔY/Y = αΔK/K + (1-α)ΔL/L + ΔA/A. Solow residual ΔA/A = ΔY/Y - αΔK/K - (1-α)ΔL/L measures TFP growth.

mathematical_formulation.capital_accumulation: dK/dt = sY - δK (investment = savings minus depreciation)
mathematical_formulation.per_effective_worker_dynamics: dk̃/dt = sf(k̃) - (δ + n + g)k̃ = sk̃ᵅ - (δ + n + g)k̃
mathematical_formulation.golden_rule_condition: f'(k̃*) = δ + n + g, or αk̃*^(α-1) = δ + n + g
mathematical_formulation.convergence_speed: λ = (1-α)(δ + n + g) ≈ 2-3% per year (half-life ~25-35 years)

level_vs_growth.savings_rate: Higher s → higher k*, y* level, but NO effect on long-run growth rate
level_vs_growth.population_growth: Higher n → lower k*, y* level (capital spread thinner)
level_vs_growth.technology: Higher g → higher growth rate of Y/L in steady state

convergence.absolute: All countries converge to same steady state - FALSE (different s, n, institutions)
convergence.conditional: Countries converge to OWN steady state - TRUE (supported by data)
convergence.speed: About 2% per year - half of gap closed in ~35 years

predictions.transition_growth: Countries below k* grow faster than those at k* - observed in Japan, Germany, China
predictions.diminishing_returns: Investment booms eventually fade as steady state approached
predictions.technology_is_key: Long-run growth differences must reflect TFP/technology differences

provenance.verification_notes: Content verified against Solow (1956) original paper and standard textbooks. Mathematical derivations confirmed. Empirical predictions cross-checked with growth literature. Convergence estimates from Barro & Sala-i-Martin (1992).

verified_claims.derivation: Steady state: sk̃ᵅ = (δ+n+g)k̃. Divide: sk̃^(α-1) = δ+n+g. So k̃^(1-α) = s/(δ+n+g). Taking 1/(1-α) power: k̃* = [s/(δ+n+g)]^(1/(1-α)) ✓

verified_claims.claim: Golden rule savings rate equals capital share (s_gold = α)
verified_claims.derivation: c̃* = f(k̃*) - (δ+n+g)k̃*. Max: f'(k̃*) = δ+n+g. With f = k̃ᵅ: αk̃*^(α-1) = δ+n+g. Substitute k̃* formula, solve: s = α ✓

verified_claims.claim: Only technological progress sustains long-run per capita growth
verified_claims.derivation: In steady state: k̃* constant, ỹ* constant. But y = Y/L = Aỹ. Since A grows at rate g, Y/L grows at rate g. Without g, Y/L is constant in steady state ✓
